facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 197 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 197 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 6, 1954, of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 30 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 6,1954, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 30 of 1954,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated January 28, 1954, of Bombay High Court in Insolvency No. 74 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 28, 1954, of the said High Court in Insolvency No. 74 of 1951.

facts.text: Deed of gift executed by insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of appellants (wife and three sons).

anchor.surface_text: a deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void.

facts.text: Creditors of Daulatram filed petition in Bombay High Court, Insolvency Case No. 74 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: some creditors of Daulatram filed a petition in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, Insolvency Case No. 74 of 1.951,

facts.text: Daulatram gave notice of suspension of payment of debts on August 2, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: for an order that the said Daulatram be adjudged insolvent as he had given numberice of suspension of payment of the debts on August 2, 1951.

facts.text: Daulatram adjudicated insolvent on August 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Daulatram was adjudicated in- solvent on August 21, 1951,

facts.text: Estate of insolvent vested in respondent official assignee under s.17 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that the estate of the insolvent vested in the respondent under s. 17 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent took out notice of motion on September 26, 1951, under s.55 Presidency Towns Insolvency Act.

anchor.surface_text: On September 26, 1951, the respondent took out the present numberice of motion.

facts.text: Appellants 1 to 3 filed joint affidavit claiming deed was transaction supported by valuable consideration, not gift.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to the numberice of motion appellants I to 3 filed a joint affidavit setting out the facts and circumstances under which the said deed of gift had been executed by the insolvent in their favour.

facts.text: At hearing before Mr. Justice Coyajee, respondent objected to appellants' evidence under s.92 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this numberice of motion before Mr. Justice Coyajee, when the appellants sought to lead evidence in support of this plea, the respondent objected and urged that the evidence which the appellants wanted to lead was inadmissible under s. 92 of the Indian Evidence Act.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Coyajee overruled objection and allowed appellants to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge, however, overruled the respondents objection and allowed the appellants to lead 1386 their evidence.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Coyajee rejected appellants' contention and granted declaration under s.55 on January 28, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the end the learned Judge did number accept the appellants companytention and, by his judgment delivered on January 28, 1954, he granted the declaration claimed by the respondent under s. 55 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants preferred Appeal No. 30 of 1954 before Chagla C.J. and Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment and order the appellants preferred an appeal  No. 30 of 1954  which was heard by Chagla C. J. and Shah J.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed appeal on August 6, 1954, holding error in allowing oral evidence under s.92.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the appeal preferred by the appellants was dismissed on August 6, 1964.

facts.text: High Court rejected certificate on September 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1954, the application made by the appellants for a certificate was rejected by the High Court at Bombay

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on November 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: but special leave was granted to the appellants by this Court on November 3, 1954,

facts.text: Appellants are wife and three sons of insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned deed of gift has been executed by the insolvent in favour of his wife and three sons who are the appellants before us.

facts.text: Respondent official assignee moved under s.55 for declaration that deed void.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from the numberice of motion taken out by the respondent official assignee under s. 55 of the Presidency towns Insolvency Act against the appellants for a declaration that a deed of gift

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J. on February 20, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. February 20. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.92 Evidence Act inapplicable as official assignee not representative-in-interest of insolvent.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that s. 92 is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings and so the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of the plea raised by them.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court decree and remanded for disposal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the companyrt of appeal in the High Court at Bombay and send the appeal back to that Court for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

This appeal by special leave arises from the notice of motion taken out by the respondent official assignee under s. 55 of the Presidency towns Insolvency Act against the appellants for a declaration that a deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void.

issues.text: The principal point which arises in this appeal is whether the appellants were entitled to lead oral evidence with a view to show the real nature of the impugned transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which arises in this appeal is whether the appellants were entitled to lead oral evidence with a view to show the real nature of the impugned transaction. In deciding this question, it would be necessary to consider the true scope and effect of ss. 91 and 92 of the Evidence Act.

issues.text: Whether the deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void under s. 55 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from the notice of motion taken out by the respondent official assignee under s. 55 of the Presidency towns Insolvency Act against the appellants for a declaration that a deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void.

arguments.claim: The deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void under s.55 of the Presidency Towns Insolvency Act.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from the notice of motion taken out by the respondent official assignee under s. 55 of the Presidency towns Insolvency Act against the appellants for a declaration that a deed of gift executed by the insolvent Daulatram Hukamchand on May 22, 1950, in favour of the appellants was void.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: on January 28, 1954, he granted the declaration claimed by the respondent under s. 55 of the Act. Ag

arguments.court_reasoning: Lower court (Coyajee J) granted declaration on merits after allowing evidence; High Court upheld on evidence point but SC set aside for remand on merits.

arguments.claim: The transaction evidenced by the deed of gift was really a transaction supported by valuable consideration and as such did not fall within the mischief of s.55 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to the notice of motion appellants I to 3 filed a joint affidavit setting out the facts and circumstances under which the said deed of gift had been executed by the insolvent in their favour. In substance, the appellants case was that, though the document purported to be a gift, it was really a transaction supported by valuable consideration and as such it did not fall within the mischief of s. 55 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The evidence which the appellants wanted to lead was inadmissible under s.92 of the Indian Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this notice of motion before Mr. Justice Coyajee, when the appellants sought to lead evidence in support of this plea, the respondent objected and urged that the evidence which the appellants wanted to lead was inadmissible under s. 92 of the Indian Evidence Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n the provisions of s. 91 read with s. 99 of the Act. He companytends that s. 91 requires the production and proof of the document itself for the purp

arguments.court_reasoning: s.92 inapplicable as official assignee not representative-in-interest of insolvent.

arguments.claim: Mr. Justice Coyajee erred in law in allowing oral evidence to be led by the appellants; under s.92, not open to show transaction supported by valuable consideration instead of natural love and affection.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges took the view that Mr. Justice Coyajee had erred in law in allowing oral evidence to be led by the appellants in support of their plea that the transaction evidenced by the deed of gift was in reality a transfer for consideration. The learned Judges held that the gift in question had been executed by the donor in favour of the donees out of natural love and affection and that, under s. 92, it was not open to the appellants to lead evidence to show that the transaction was supported not by the consideration of natural love and affection but by another kind of valuable consideration.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n the provisions of s. 91 read with s. 99 of the Act. He companytends that s. 91 requires the production and proof of the document itself for the purp

arguments.court_reasoning: s.92 does not apply to proceedings between official assignee (stranger) and donees; lack of mutuality.

arguments.claim: s.92 applies to present proceedings between official assignee and donees as assignee represents insolvent as representative-in-interest.

anchor.surface_text: before considering the effect of the provisions of s. 92 in regard to the appellants right to lead oral evidence, it would be necessary to examine whether s. 92 applies at all to the present proceedings between the official assignee who is the respondent and the donees from the insolvent who are the appellants before us. Does the official assignee represent the insolvent, and can he be described as the representative-ininterest of the insolvent,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: claimed by the official assignee under s. 55 has already gone out of the estate of the insolvent, and it cannot be said to vest in the official assig

arguments.court_reasoning: Official assignee acts for creditors' benefit under s.55, not for or on behalf of insolvent; property already transferred out; higher title than insolvent.

arguments.claim: Official assignee does not represent the insolvent or act as representative-in-interest when moving under s.55 PTIA.

anchor.surface_text: Does the official assignee represent the insolvent, and can he be described as the representative-ininterest of the insolvent, when he moves the Insolvency Court under s. 55 of the Presidency-towns Insolvency Act ? It is true that, under s. 17 of the Act, on the making of an order of adjudication, the property of the insolvent wherever situate vests in the official assignee and becomes divisible among his creditors but the property in respect of which a declaration is claimed by the official assignee under s. 55 has already gone out of the estate of the insolvent,

arguments.claim: Proceedings under s.55 are by Insolvency Court in exercise of exclusive jurisdiction for creditors' benefit, not on behalf of insolvent.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that it is the Insolvency Court alone which has jurisdiction to annul the insolvents transactions, whether the case is governed by the Presidency-towns Insolvency Act or by the Provincial Insolvency Act

arguments.claim: s.55 makes transfers voidable at instance of official assignee for benefit of creditors; analogous to creditor applications where s.92 would not apply.

anchor.surface_text: This section, like s. 53-A of the Provincial Insolvency Act, makes the impugned transfers voidable at the instance of the official assignee or the receiver. ... Similarly, under s. 54-A of the Provincial Insolvency Act, a creditor himself can make the application if the receiver refuses to take any action.

arguments.claim: Appellants as representatives-in-interest cannot invoke s.92 against stranger (official assignee); rule of exclusion based on mutuality inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised by Shri Purushottam which still remains to be considered is whether the appellants who undoubtedly are the representatives in interest of the insolvent can avoid the application of s. 92. In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the appellants.

arguments.claim: s.91 excludes oral evidence of agreements affecting terms by necessary implication when read with s.99.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Purushottam bases his argument mainly on the provisions of s. 91 read with s. 99 of the Act. He contends that s. 91 requires the production and proof of the document itself for the purpose of proving the contents of the document and by necessary implication all evidence about any oral agreement which may affect the terms of the document is excluded by s. 91 itself.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: icial assignee also cannot be said to be the repre

arguments.court_reasoning: ss.91 and 92 supplement each other; s.91 only excludes proof of contents, not variation by oral agreement which is for s.92.

arguments.claim: s.99 only allows strangers to lead evidence varying terms, prohibiting parties/representatives independently of s.92.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Purushottam also relied upon the provisions of s. 99. His argument is that it is only persons who are not parties to a document or their representatives in interest who are allowed by s. 99 to give evidence of facts tending to show a contemporaneous agreement varying the terms of the document.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: icial assignee also cannot be said to be the repre

arguments.court_reasoning: s.99 clarifies position for strangers; does not prohibit parties by implication when s.92 inapplicable; mutuality doctrine.

arguments.claim: s.91 based on best evidence rule, requires document for contents; s.92 excludes oral agreements to contradict/vary terms between parties/reps.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VI of the Evidence Act which begins with s. 91 deals with the exclusion of oral by documentary evidence. Section 91 provides that, when the terms of a contract, or of a grant, or of any other disposition of property, have been reduced to the form of a document, ... The application of this rule is limited to cases as between parties to the instrument or their representatives in interest.

arguments.claim: Strangers not bound by s.92; s.99 allows evidence of contemporaneous agreements varying terms; applies to contradict/add/subtract too.

anchor.surface_text: This position is made absolutely clear by the provisions of s. 99 itself. Section 99 provides that persons who are not parties to a document or their representatives in interest may give evidence of any facts tending to show a contemporaneous agreement varying the terms of the document.

arguments.claim: s.92 exclusion based on mutuality; inequitable to apply against party when opposed by stranger.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of exclusion enunciated by s. 92 applies to both parties to the document and is based on the doctrine of mutuality. It would be inequitable and unfair to enforce that rule against a party to a document or his representative in interest in the case of a dispute between the said party or his representative in interest on the one hand and the stranger on the other.

arguments.claim: s.92 wholly inapplicable; appellants entitled to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that s. 92 is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings and so the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of the plea raised by them.

holdings.text: Section 92 of the Evidence Act is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings between the official assignee and the donees from the insolvent, and the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of their plea.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that s. 92 is wholly inapplicable to the present proceedings and so the appellants are entitled to lead evidence in support of the plea raised by them. It appears that the attention of the learned Judges who heard the appeal in the High Court at Bombay was not drawn to this aspect of the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.92 applies only between parties or their representatives in interest; official assignee is stranger acting for creditors, not insolvent; doctrine of mutuality prevents application against donees when opposed by stranger.

holdings.text: The official assignee does not represent the insolvent and cannot be described as the representative-in-interest of the insolvent when moving under s.55 of the Presidency-towns Insolvency Act.

anchor.surface_text: Does the official assignee represent the insolvent, and can he be described as the representative-ininterest of the insolvent, when he moves the Insolvency Court under s. 55 of the Presidency-towns Insolvency Act ? It is true that, under s. 17 of the Act, on the making of an order of adjudication, the property of the insolvent wherever situate vests in the official assignee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s.55, official assignee acts for benefit of creditors, not insolvent; property already transferred out; higher title; analogous to creditor applications; exclusive jurisdiction of Insolvency Court for creditors.

holdings.text: The appellants, though representatives in interest of the insolvent, can lead oral evidence to vary terms of the document because s.92 does not apply against them when opposed by a stranger like the official assignee.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised by Shri Purushottam which still remains to be considered is whether the appellants who undoubtedly are the representatives in interest of the insolvent can avoid the application of s. 92. In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.92 based on mutuality; inequitable to exclude evidence from party when stranger can lead it; s.99 clarifies strangers not bound; no prohibition by implication on parties when s.92 inapplicable.

holdings.text: The decree passed by the Court of Appeal in the High Court at Bombay must be set aside and the appeal sent back for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the court of appeal in the High Court at Bombay and send the appeal back to that Court for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in applying s.92; attention not drawn to correct position; merits not decided due to evidence ruling.

holdings.text: Sections 91 and 92 of the Evidence Act supplement each other; s.91 requires proof of document contents by the document itself (best evidence rule), s.92 excludes oral agreements contradicting/varying terms between parties/representatives.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VI of the Evidence Act which begins with s. 91 deals with the exclusion of oral by documentary evidence. Section 91 provides that, when the terms of a contract, or of a grant, or of any other disposition of property, have been reduced to the form of a document, and in all cases in which any matter is required by law to be reduced to the form of a document, noevidence shall be given in proof of the terms of such contract, grant or other disposition of property,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of ss.91,92; s.91 exclusive for contents, s.92 for variations post-proof under s.91.

holdings.text: Strangers to a document are not bound by s.92 and may give evidence to contradict, vary, add to or subtract from its terms, as clarified by s.99.

anchor.surface_text: This position is made absolutely clear by the provisions of s. 99 itself. Section 99 provides that persons who are not parties to a document or their representatives in interest may give evidence of any facts tending to show a contemporaneous agreement varying the terms of the document. Though it is only variation which is specifically mentioned in s. 99, there can be nodoubt that the third partys right to lead evidence which is recognized by s. 99 would include, a right to lead evidence not only to vary the terms of the document, but to contradict the said terms or to add to or subtract from them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.99 extending to contradiction etc.; supplements s.92.

anchor.surface_text: R. Cheadle, 3 B. and Ad. 833  number, in proceedings between a party and a stranger, will the former be estopped, since there would be numbermutuality  1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: extrinsic evidence to contradict or vary the writing is excluded only in proceedings between such parties or their privies, and not in those between strangers, or a party and a stranger since strangers cannot be precluded from proving the truth by the ignorance, carelessness, or fraud of the parties

anchor.surface_text: The question raised by Shri Purushottam which still remains to be considered is whether the appellants who undoubtedly are the representatives in interest of the insolvent can avoid the application of s. 92. In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in favour of the appellants.
We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the companyrt of appeal in the High Court at Bombay and send the appeal back to that Court for disposal on the merits in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VI of the Evidence Act which begins with s. 91 deals with the exclusion of oral by documentary evidence. Section 91 provides that, when the terms of a contract, or of a grant, or of any other disposition of property, have been reduced to the form of a document, and in all cases in which any matter is required by law to be reduced to the form of a document, noevidence shall be given in proof of the terms of such contract, grant or other disposition of property,
